choices.text: Eggs laid in rafts without lateral floats
Larvae suspended vertically with head down
Palpi are long in both sexes

questions.text: Which of the following features is characteristic of Anopheles mosquitoes and not seen in Culex or Aedes mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Palpi are long in both sexes is a distinguishing feature of Anopheles adults.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by mosquitoes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kyasanur Forest Disease is not mosquito-borne but transmitted by hard ticks.

questions.text: Identify the mosquito genus based on the adult posture shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Body rests at an angle to the surface and wings are spotted features characteristic of Anopheles mosquito.

Comparison of Mosquito Tribes:

questions.text: Which type of mosquito typically breeds in polluted or dirty water collections?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Culex mosquitoes breed in dirty or polluted water.

Breeding Habits of Mosquitos:

  • Anopheles: Breed in clean water (Option A)
  • Culex: Breed in dirty/polluted water (Option B)
  • Aedes: Breed in artificial water collections (Option C)
  • Mansonia: Breed in water with aquatic vegetation (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an anti-larval measure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pyrethrum is an adulticide used to kill adult mosquitoes.

Anti-Larval Measures:

  • Environmental Control (Source Reduction):
    • Eliminate breeding sites via:
      • Filling, drainage, levelling.
      • Water management (e.g., intermittent irrigation).
      • Changing the salinity of water.
    • Species-specific actions:
      • Culex: Remove sewage pools, ditches.
      • Aedes: Eliminate containers (tins, pots, shells).
      • Anopheles: Fill stagnant water bodies.
      • Mansonia: Remove aquatic plants/herbicide use.
    • Permanent effect if maintained.
  • Chemical Control:
    • Mineral Oils:
      • Forms a film on water; suffocates larvae/pupae.
      • Applied weekly; 40-90 L/ha.
      • Not suitable for drinking water, kills fish.
    • Paris Green: (Option A)
      • Stomach poison; kills surface-feeding larvae (Anopheles).
      • Safe for fish/humans.
      • 2% dust, 1 kg/ha.
    • Synthetic Insecticides:
      • Fenthion, Chlorpyrifos, Abate (organophosphates. (Option B)
      • Rapidly degrade in water.
      • Abate (1 ppm) is effective and low toxicity.
      • Avoid DDT, HCH due to resistance and pollution.
  • Biological Control:
    • Larvivorous fish: Gambusia, Lebistes. (Option C)
    • Used in ponds, cisterns, and oxidation pits.
    • Supplementary to other methods.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an anti-adult mosquito control measure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gambusia affinis is a larvivorous fish used to kill mosquito larvae, not adults.

Anti-Adult Mosquito Measures:

  • Residual Sprays: (Option A)
    • Most common method for adult mosquito control.
    • Involves spraying residual insecticides on walls and resting surfaces.
    • Insecticide of choice:
      • DDT at 1-2 grams per square meter.
      • Applied 1-3 times a year.
    • Alternatives in case of resistance:
      • Malathion, Propoxur
      • Gamma-HCH (lindane)
  • Space Sprays:
    • Sprayed into air as mist or fog to kill mosquitoes.
    • Pyrethrum extract commonly used: (Option B)
      • Derived from pyrethrum flowers.
      • Contains pyrethrin, a nerve poison.
      • Kills mosquitoes instantly on contact.
  • Genetic Control (Still in Research Phase):
    • Promising non-chemical methods under research:
      • Sterile male technique (Option D)
      • Cytoplasmic incompatibility
      • Chromosomal translocations
      • Sex distortion
      • Gene replacement

choices.text: Diethyltoluamide (DEET) provides protection for up to 18-20 hours.
Mosquito nets should be white and about 150 holes per square inch
Screening with copper gauze should have 6 meshes per inch
Repellents are mainly applied on the skin for short-term protection

questions.text: Which of the following statements about protection against mosquito bites is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Effective mosquito screening requires 16 meshes per inch, not 6.

Protection Against Mosquito Bites:

  • Mosquito Nets:
    • Provide protection during sleep.
    • Material: Preferably white, helps detect mosquitoes easily.
    • Design: Best type is rectangular with netting on top and sides.
    • No holes or tears should be present.
    • Mesh size:
      • Hole size should not exceed 0.0475 inch in diameter.
      • Usually 150 holes per square inch. (Option B)
  • Screening of Buildings:
    • Use copper or bronze gauze for window/door screening.
    • Mesh requirement: 16 meshes per inch. (Option C)
    • Aperture: Should not exceed 0475 inch.
    • Costly, but highly effective.
  • Repellents (Culicifuges):
    • Main use: Applied on skin for short-term protection. (Option D)
    • Most effective: Diethyltoluamide (DEET), effective against Culex fatigans for 18-20 hours. (Option A)
    • Other effective repellents:
      • Indalone
      • Dimethyl phthalate
      • Dimethyl carbate
      • Ethyl hexanediol

questions.text: As per International Health Regulations (IHR), the minimum distance around airports or seaports that must be kept free from mosquitoes is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • International Health Regulations recommend that all international seaports and airports be kept free of vector mosquitoes within a 400-meter perimeter for public health safety.
  • This requires regular vector surveillance and appropriate control measures in and around the ports.

Reference:

https://www.ijcmas.com/10-8-2021/K.%20Regu,%20et%20al.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following best describes sullage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sullage refers to wastewater from non-toilet domestic activities, especially from the kitchen, bathroom, and laundry.
  • It typically contains organic matter, soap, grease, food particles, and detergents, but does not include human excreta.
  • It is also known as grey water, and it differs from sewage, which contains both sullage and toilet waste.

Explanation of other options:

Solid vegetable waste matter (Option A) refers to solid organic kitchen waste such as peels, stems, and leftover vegetable parts. It is solid waste, not liquid wastewater, and therefore not classified as sullage.

Inorganic waste (Option B) includes non-biodegradable materials like plastics, metals, and glass. These are solid wastes, not household wastewater. Hence, they do not fall under the category of sullage.

Waste containing human excreta (Option C) is known as sewage or black water, originating from toilets and urinals. Sullage specifically excludes human excreta and comes from non-toilet sources such as kitchens and bathrooms.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a confirmatory test for coliform detection in water analysis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Eijkman's test confirms the presence of E. coli by demonstrating lactose fermentation with gas production at 44°C.

Presumptive Coliform Test:

  1. Multiple Tube Method:
    • Purpose: Estimate the Most Probable Number (MPN) of coliform organisms in 100 ml of water.
    • Procedure:
      • Inoculate different volumes of water sample (1 ml, 1 ml, 10 ml, 50 ml) into tubes of MacConkey's Lactose Bile Salt Broth.
      • Use bromocresol purple as a pH indicator.
      • Incubate tubes at 37°C for 48 hours.
    • Interpretation:
      • Tubes showing acid and gas production are counted.
      • Use MPN statistical tables to estimate coliform count.
      • Result is called "Presumptive Coliform Count".
      • Presumption: Each positive tube contains coliform organisms, though false positives may occur due to non-coliforms.
  2. Confirmatory Tests:
    • Eijkman's Test:
      • This is the incubation at 44°C
      • coli is one of the few coliforms that can ferment lactose with gas production at 44°C.
      • Hence, positive gas production at 44°C confirms presence of coli.
    • Further Confirmation:
      • Indole production test at 44°C can further confirm coli identity.
  3. Membrane Filtration Technique:
    • Alternative standard method used in some countries.
    • Procedure:
      • Filter a measured volume of water through a cellulose ester membrane.
      • Bacteria are trapped on the membrane surface.
      • Place the membrane face-up on a selective culture medium.
      • Incubate at an appropriate temperature.
    • Advantages:
      • Enables direct colony count.
      • Rapid results within 20 hours, compared to 72-96 hours for MPN method.

Explanation of other options:

Casoni's test (Option B): Used for diagnosing hydatid disease caused by Echinococcus granulosus. It has no role in coliform detection or water testing.

Nitrate test (Option C): Detects nitrate-reducing bacteria. While some coliforms can reduce nitrate, this test is not specific for confirming coliform presence.

Urease test (Option D): Identifies urease-producing bacteria. Although some coliforms may produce urease, this test is not reliable or specific for coliform confirmation in water.

questions.text: Ortho-toluidine test is used to detect which of the following in water by producing a yellow colour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When ortho-toluidine reagent is added, it reacts with chlorine to produce a yellow color, whose intensity indicates the chlorine concentration.

Orthotolidine (OT) Test:

  • Purpose:
    • Known for its speed and accuracy.
    • To detect and estimate both free and combined chlorine in water.
  • Reagent Composition:
    • Orthotolidine (analytical grade) dissolved in 10% hydrochloric acid.
  • Principle:
    • When OT reagent is added to chlorinated water, it turns yellow.
    • The intensity of the yellow colour varies with the chlorine concentration.
    • Free chlorine reacts instantaneously.
    • Combined chlorine reacts slowly.
  • Procedure:
    • Add 1 ml of OT reagent to 1 ml of water sample.
    • Observe the yellow colour
  • Interpretation:
    • Immediate reading (within 10 seconds): Indicates free chlorine
    • Delayed reading (after 15-20 minutes): Reflects total chlorine (free + combined).
    • Colour intensity is matched with standards or colour discs.

Explanation of other options:

Ozone (Option A) is also used as a disinfectant in water treatment, but the ortho-toluidine test is not designed to detect ozone. It is specific for chlorine detection.

RO Filtration (Option B): Reverse Osmosis (RO) is a physical filtration process for removing contaminants using a semipermeable membrane. OT test is not related to assessing RO performance; it is used specifically for chemical testing of chlorine.

coli (Option D) is an indicator of fecal contamination in water, detected using microbiological tests like membrane filtration or enzyme-based assays. OT test does not detect bacteria; it is used for chlorine estimation only.

questions.text: Reduviid bug is a vector for the transmission of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chagas disease is caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi, which is transmitted to humans by Reduviid bugs.

Reduviid Bugs (Cone-nose bugs):

  • General Characteristics:
    • Vectors of Chagas' disease (Trypanosoma cruzi) in Mexico and Central/South America.
    • Large size: About 1 inch or more in length.
    • Adults are winged.
    • Blood-sucking insects, feed on animals and humans.
  • Medical Importance:
    • Transmit Chagas' disease outside India.
    • Their bites can cause:
      • Intense itching
      • Nausea
      • Flushed face
      • Palpitations
  • Habitat & Behavior:
    • Hide in cracks and crevices of walls, ceilings, and animal shelters.
    • Nocturnal feeders, emerge only to feed and then hide again.
    • Thrive in primitive housing conditions.
    • Control Measures:
      • Residual insecticide spraying:
        • HCH - 0.5 g/m2
        • Dieldrin - 1 g/m2

Explanation of other options:

Relapsing fever (Option A): Transmitted by lice or soft ticks, not reduviid bugs.

Lyme's disease (Option B): Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, spread by Ixodes ticks.

Scrub typhus (Option C): Caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, transmitted by chigger mites, not bugs.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the sandfly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trench fever is caused by Bartonella quintana and transmitted by the body louse, not by sandflies.

Diseases Transmitted by Sand Fly:

  • Kala-azar
  • Sandfly Fever
  • Oriental sore
  • Oraya fever

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the rat flea?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Relapsing fever is caused by Borrelia species, transmitted by lice or soft ticks, not by rat fleas.

Diseases Transmitted by Rat Flea:

  1. Plague (bubonic)
  2. Murine Typhus (Endemic typhus)
  3. Chiggerosis
  4. Hymenolepis diminuta

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by lice?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness, it is transmitted by the blackfly, not by lice.

Diseases Transmitted by Louse:

  • Epidemic Typhus
  • Relapsing Fever
  • Trench Fever
  • Pediculosis

choices.text: Can survive starvation for a year or more

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of hard ticks (Ixodidae)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Soft ticks, not hard ticks, can survive starvation for over a year.

Comparison of Hard and Soft Ticks:

questions.text: A child presents with multiple itchy papular lesions over the fingers and genitalia. His younger sibling has similar complaints. The itching is worse at night. An image of the causative vector is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of itchy papular lesions on fingers and genitalia, along with similar symptoms in a sibling, together with an image showing Sarcoptes scabiei, strongly points towards scabies.

Scabies:

  • Caused by Sarcoptes scabiei.
  • Female mite burrows into epidermis → causes scabies.
  • Animal mites cannot survive on human skin.
  • Mode of Spread:
    • Close contact (most common) - familial spread.
    • Contaminated clothes/linen - less common.
  • Common Sites:
    • Hands & wrists (63%), elbows (10.9%), axillae, buttocks, abdomen, ankles, feet.
    • Palms (infants), breasts (women), genitals (men).
  • Diagnosis:
    • Night-time itching.
    • Follicular lesions.
    • Crusted papules/pustules (secondary infection).
    • Household members affected.
    • Mite seen under microscope.
  • Treatment:
    • Treat all household members.
    • Wash with soap and hot water before application.
    • Drugs:
      • Benzyl benzoate (25%) - apply twice in 24 hrs, max 2×/week.
      • Gamma-HCH (0.5-1%) - apply twice, 2-3 days apart.
      • Tetmosol (5%) - daily × 3 days.
      • Sulphur ointment (2.5-10%) - daily × 4 days.

Explanation of other options:

Papular urticaria (Option A): Typically caused by insect bites; lesions are scattered, not in classic scabies sites like web spaces or genitalia, and not usually familial.

Atopic dermatitis (Option C): A chronic condition with flexural involvement; genital lesions and sudden familial spread are uncommon.

Allergic contact dermatitis (Option D): Confined to specific contact areas; unlikely to affect multiple family members in the same pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of transovarial transmission in arthropod vectors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rickettsia rickettsii is transmitted vertically from adult tick to its eggs through transovarial transmission.

  • TOT is an efficient vertical transmission of pathogens.
  • Observed Only in:
    • Babesia sensu stricto (Clade VI)
    • Rickettsia spp.
  • Transovarial transmission does not significantly contribute to the amplification of tick-borne pathogens but plays a crucial role in maintaining the pathogen within the tick population and the environment.

Explanation of other options:

Plague bacilli in rat flea (Option A): Yersinia pestis is not transmitted transovarially; fleas transmit it via regurgitation during a blood meal after blockage of their gut.

Malarial parasite in mosquito (Option B): Plasmodium is acquired by mosquitoes during a blood meal and develops within them, but not passed to their offspring, hence, no transovarial transmission.

Microfilaria in mosquito (Option C): Microfilariae are taken up during a blood meal and develop into infective larvae inside the mosquito (transstadial), but are not inherited via eggs.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9936132/

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of cyclo-developmental transmission?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wuchereria bancrofti in mosquitoes undergoes cyclo-developmental transmission.

Biological Transmission of Parasites:

  • The infectious agent undergoes replication, development, or both within the vector.
  • Requires an incubation period before the vector can transmit the agent.
  • Types of Biological Transmission:
    1. Propagative Transmission:
      • Agent multiplies in the vector.
      • No change in form.
      • Example:
        • Yersinia pestis (plague bacillus) in rat fleas. (Option A)
        • Trypanosoma cruzi (Chagas disease) in a reduviid bug. (Option D)
    2. Cyclo-propagative Transmission:
      • Agent undergoes multiplication and change in form.
      • Example: Plasmodium (malaria parasite) in a mosquito. (Option B)
    3. Cyclo-developmental Transmission:
      • Agent undergoes development only, no multiplication.
      • Example: Wuchereria bancrofti (microfilaria) in a mosquito. (Option C)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding arthropod control is/are correct?
4. Sterile male technique is a part of chemical control..Environmental control offers the most permanent results in arthropod control.
2.Resistance to insecticides has appeared in over 100 species of arthropods.
3Larvivorous fish, such as Gambusia, are used in biological control.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The correct statements are 1, 2 and 3 only.

Principles of Arthropod Control:

  1. Environmental Control: (Best and Permanent Approach) (Statement 1)
    • Eliminates breeding sites (source reduction).
    • Methods:
      • Filling & drainage
      • Water management
      • Piped water supply
      • Proper waste disposal
      • Household & surrounding cleanliness
  2. Chemical Control:
    • Insecticides used: Organochlorines, Organophosphates, Carbamates.
    • Challenges:
      • Resistance in >100 arthropod species. (Statement 2)
      • Environmental contamination.
    • Solution:
      • Gradual shift from persistent agents (e.g., DDT) to biodegradable, less toxic ones like:
        • Methoxychlor
        • Abate
        • Dursban
  3. Biological Control:
    • Reduces toxic chemical use.
    • Methods:
      • Larvivorous fish (e.g., Gambusia) (Statement 3)
      • Fungi (Coelomomyces) pathogenic to mosquitoes
  4. Genetic Control:
    • Techniques developed by the WHO/ICMR Unit, New Delhi.
    • Methods:
      • Sterile male technique (Statement 4)
      • Cytoplasmic incompatibility
      • Chromosomal translocations
    • Effective in small field trials, but not yet ready for large-scale use.

questions.text:
Organophosphate insecticides are all except
A. Dieldrin
B. Fenthion
C. Diazinon
D. Propoxur
E. Lindane
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dieldrin and Lindane are organochlorines, while Propoxur is a carbamate, not an organophosphate.

Organo-phosphorus Insecticides:

choices.text: It acts as a strong insect repellent.
Its residual action can last up to 18 months on certain surfaces.
It is highly soluble in water.
Immediate death of insects occurs after contact.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding DDT is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

DDT's residual insecticidal effect can persist for up to 18 months on treated surfaces, though less on mud walls.

DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-trichloroethane):

  • Properties:
    • White amorphous powder with mild, non-unpleasant smell.
    • Insoluble in water; soluble in most organic solvents. (Option C)
  • Mode of Action:
    • Contact poison acting on insect nervous system.
    • Enters via cuticle after dissolving in waxy covering of insect feet.
    • Causes paralysis of legs/wings → convulsions → death (not immediate; takes hours). (Option D)
    • Residual action: up to 18 months (reduced on mud walls due to absorption). (Option B)
    • No repellent action. (Option A)
  • Applications:
    • Residual spray: 100-200 mg per sq. ft; 5% suspension; 1 gallon covers 1,000 sq. ft (200 mg/sq. ft).
    • Dust form: 5-10% strength for control of lice, fleas, ticks, bugs.
    • Aerosol/space sprays: DDT as main constituent.
    • Still widely used insecticide.

choices.text: Only the female tsetse fly bites humans during nighttime
Tsetse flies are found worldwide in tropical climates
Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomiasis and have scissor-like wing folding
They lay multiple eggs in moist vegetation for larval development

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the tsetse fly (Glossina) is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Tsetse flies, found only in Africa, are vectors of trypanosomiasis and are uniquely identified by their scissor-like wing folding when at rest.

Tsetse Flies (Glossina):

  • Bloodsucking flies, yellow/dark-brown, ~½ inch long.
  • Wings fold like scissor blades.
  • Rigid, non-retractile proboscis for blood feeding.
  • Found only in Africa. (Option B)
  • Vectors of trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness) in humans and animals. (Option C)
  • Both sexes bite, mainly during the day. (Option A)
  • Life Cycle:
    • Viviparous: Female gives birth to live larvae every 10 days. (Option D)
    • Larva buries itself in soil → pupates in hours.
    • Pupal stage: 20-40 days.
    • Adult lifespan: <100 days.
  • Control Measures:
    • Insecticides: DDT (25%), Dieldrin (18-20%)
    • Vegetation clearing: Removes breeding sites.
    • Genetic control: Sterile male release under study.

questions.text: Identify the disease caused by the vector shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sleeping sickness is caused by Trypanosoma brucei, transmitted by the tsetse fly.

Tsetse Flies (Glossina):

  • Bloodsucking fly, ½ inch, yellow/brown.
  • Wings overlap like scissors; rigid proboscis.
  • Only in Africa ("fly belts").
  • Life Cycle:
    • Female: Viviparous (1 larva/10 days).
    • Larva buries ~1 inch in soil → pupates in hours.
    • Pupal stage: 20-40 days.
    • Adult lifespan: <100 days.
  • Day-biters; both sexes feed.
  • Vector: Trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness).
  • Control:
    • Insecticides: DDT 25%, Dieldrin 18-20% (aerial spraying).
    • Vegetation clearing (best with insecticides).
    • Game destruction (obsolete).
    • Genetic control (sterile male release).

Explanation of other options:

Lyme's disease (Option A): Transmitted by Ixodes ticks.

Carrion's disease (Option B): Transmitted by sandflies (Lutzomyia).

Babesiosis (Option C): Transmitted by Ixodes ticks.
